app.footer: WatchMeGrow.care is supported by the University of New South Wales. It focuses on general developmental milestones, as well as language and social skills.

landing.heading: All children grow and develop at their own pace.
landing.explanation: WatchMeGrow.care helps track your child's progress and provides information about healthy development.
landing.ages: This app is designed for children aged approximately {{minAge}} to {{maxAge}}

generalInformation.intro: For general information on growth and development for children from birth to 5 years please see the following link:

details.yourEmailAddress: Your email address (so we can send you the results)

doctorDetails.explanationPara1: Please include your health practitioner’s email address if you would like them to receive these results.
doctorDetails.explanationPara2: Alternatively, the results will also be sent to you via email for you to print and take to your health professional.

rqc.behaviour: Does the child show any difficulties with behaviour such as being overactive (e.g. cannot sit still) or lack attention and concentration (e.g. easily distracted and does not finish activities)?
rqc.calming: Does the child show difficulty in calming down or is it difficult to comfort the child?
rqc.sleep: Does the child have any sleep or related difficulty?
rqc.worries: Does the child suffer from frequent worries or fears or seem sad or unhappy for no good reason?
rqc.disobedience: Does the child frequently show lack of co-operation, disobedience, or is defiant and argumentative?
rqc.fighting: Does the child show frequent fighting or aggressive behaviour and show no regret?
rqc.feeding: Does the child have any feeding or related difficulty?
rqc.learning: Does the child have any difficulties with learning or appear to be behind for overall abilities as compared with other children of about the same age?
rqc.friendships: Does the child show no interest in friendships or nearly never play with other children or does not show concern for others?
rqc.rituals: Does the child engage in any repetitive behaviours or rituals and insist on things being done in a particular way?

cdc6.reach: Does your child try to get things that are in reach?
cdc6.affection: Does your child show affection to caregivers?
cdc6.respondToSounds: Does your child respond to sounds around them?
cdc6.difficultyMouth: Does your child have difficulty getting things to their mouth?
cdc6.vowelSounds: Can your child make vowel sounds? (“ah”, “eh”, “oh”)
cdc6.roll: Can your child roll over in either direction?
cdc6.squealing: Does your child laugh or make squealing sounds?
cdc6.tightMuscles: Is your child stiff or show signs of tight muscles, or show symptoms of being very floppy or like a rag doll?
cdc6.lostSkills: Has your child lost skills they once had?

cdc9.bearWeight: Can your child bear weight on their legs with support?
cdc9.sitWithoutHelp: Can your child sit without help?
cdc9.backAndForth: Does your child play any games involving back-and-forth play?
cdc9.respondsToOwnName: Does your child respond to their own name?
cdc9.recogniseFamiliarPeople: Does your child recognise familiar people?
cdc9.looksWhereYouPoint: Does your child look where you point?
cdc9.canTransferToys: Can your child transfer toys from one hand to another?
cdc9.lostSkills: Has your child lost any skills they once had?

cdc12.stand: Can your child stand when being supported?
cdc12.searchHidden: Does your child search for things that they see you hide?
cdc12.singleWords: Does your child say single words like "mama" or "dada"?
cdc12.gestures: Does your child use gestures like waving or shaking their head?
cdc12.point: Does your child point to things?
cdc12.lostSkills: Has your child lost any skills they once had?

cdc18.point: Does your child point to show things to others?
cdc18.knowFamiliar: Does your child know what familiar things are for (e.g. a spoon is for eating)?
cdc18.words: Does your child have at least 6 words?
cdc18.learnWords: Is your child learning new words?
cdc18.noticeCarer: Does your child notice or mind when a caregiver leaves or returns?
cdc18.lostSkills: Has your child lost skills they once had?

cdc24.twoWordPhrases: Does your child use two word phrases (e.g. “drink milk”)?
cdc24.commonThings: Does your child know what to do with common things, like a brush, phone, fork, spoon?
cdc24.copyActions: Does your child copy actions and words?
cdc24.simpleInstructions: Can your child follow simple instructions?
cdc24.walkSteady: Does your child walk steadily without assistance?
cdc24.lostSkills: Has your child lost skills they once had?

cdc36.fallDown: Does your child fall down a lot or have a lot of trouble with stairs?
cdc36.drool: Does your child drool or have very unclear speech?
cdc36.struggle: Does your child struggle to work out simple toys? (such as peg boards, simple puzzles, turning handles)?
cdc36.speak: Does your child speak in sentences?
cdc36.instructions: Does your child understand simple instructions?
cdc36.pretend: Does your child play pretend or make believe?
cdc36.toys: Does your child want to play with other children or with toys?
cdc36.eyeContact: Does your child make eye contact?
cdc36.lostSkills: Has your child lost skills they once had?

cdc48.jump: Can your child jump in one place?
cdc48.games: Does your child show any interest in interactive games or make-believe games?
cdc48.respond: Does your child ignore other children or doesn’t respond to people outside the family?
cdc48.resist: Does your child resist dressing, sleeping and using the toilet?
cdc48.retell: Can your child retell a favourite story?
cdc48.follow: Can your child follow a 3-part command?
cdc48.meYou: Can your child use “me” and “you” correctly?
cdc48.lostSkills: Has your child lost skills they once had?

cdc60.wideEmotions: Does your child show a wide amount of emotions?
cdc60.extremeBehaviour: Does your child show extreme behaviour? (usually fearful, aggressive, shy or sad)
cdc60.withdrawn: Is your child unusually withdrawn and not active?
cdc60.distracted: Is your child easily distracted, has trouble focusing on one activity for more than 5 minutes?
cdc60.respond: Does your child not respond to people, or respond only superficially?
cdc60.makeBelieve: Can your child tell the difference between what’s real and what’s make-believe?
cdc60.games: Does your child play a variety of games and activities?
cdc60.names: Can your child give their first and last name?
cdc60.plurals: Is your child able to use plurals or past tense properly?
cdc60.dailyActivities: Does your child talk about daily activities or experiences?
cdc60.brushDryWash: Is your child able to brush teeth, wash and dry hands, or get undressed without help?
cdc60.lostSkills: Has your child lost skills they once had?

qchat.lookAtYou: Does your child look at you when you call his/her name?
qchat.eyeContactEasiness: How easy is it for you to get eye contact with your child?
qchat.pointWant: Does your child point to indicate that s/he wants something? (e.g. a toy that is out of reach)
qchat.pointShareInterest: Does your child point to share interest with you (e.g. pointing at an interesting sight)?
qchat.pretending: Does your child pretend (e.g. care for dolls, talk on a toy phone)?
qchat.followLooking: Does your child follow where you’re looking?
qchat.comfort: If you or someone else in the family is visibly upset, does your child show signs of wanting to comfort them(e.g. stroking their hair, hugging them)?
qchat.firstWords: Would you describe your child’s first words as:
qchat.simpleGestures: Does your child use simple gestures (e.g. wave goodbye)?
qchat.stareAtNothing: Does your child stare at nothing with no apparent purpose?

pdq1.pointsOrGestures: My child points or gestures to show interest or get attention
pdq1.unusualResponses: My child has unusual or variable responses to sound (seems not to hear or is oversensitive or overreacts)
pdq1.smiles: My child smiles or makes regular eye contact with others
pdq1.respondsToName: My child responds to name when called
pdq1.showsInterest: My child shows interest in children at play
pdq1.relatesToOthers: My child relates to others by babbling, gesturing, talking or changing expressions
pdq1.usesThreeOrMoreWordsRegularly: My child uses 3 or more words regularly and appropriately
pdq1.speaksInPhrases: My child speaks in phrases (for example: want juice, go bye-bye, more candy, give please)
pdq1.laughsWhenOthersLaugh: My child laughs when others laugh
pdq1.stoppedUsingWords: My child stopped using words or relating to others (at any time)

asq10.noticesSmallSounds: S/he often notices small sounds when others do not
asq10.concentratesOnWholePicture: S/he usually concentrates more on the whole picture, rather than the small details
asq10.tracksMultipleConversations: In a social group, s/he can easily keep track of several different people’s conversations
asq10.goesBackAndForth: S/he finds it easy to go back and forth between different activities
asq10.doesntKnowHowToKeepConvoGoing: S/he doesn’t know how to keep a conversation going with his/her peers
asq10.goodAtChitChat: S/he is good at social chit-chat
asq10.difficultToWorkOutFeelings: When s/he is read a story, s/he finds it difficult to work out the character’s intentions or feelings
asq10.enjoyedPretending: When s/he was in preschool, s/he used to enjoy playing games involving pretending with other children
asq10.easyToWorkOutFeelings: S/he finds it easy to work out what someone is thinking or feeling just by looking at their face
asq10.hardToMakeFriends: S/he finds it hard to make new friends

results.greenFlag: Your child is developing as expected for their age. Based on your answers you have no concerns about how your child is developing.
results.redFlag: Your answers indicate that your child could benefit from a more detailed assessment. Please discuss these results with your health professional.
results.raisingChildrenIntro: All children grow and develop at their own pace. Please use the following link to access information on what is expected for your child's age.

results.intro: Thank you for completing WatchMeGrow.care for

reminder.thankYouPara: Thank you for previously completing the WatchMeGrow.care app. It is recommended that you complete this when your child is aged approximately
reminder.reminderPara: This is a reminder to complete the WatchMeGrow.care app for your child again. As before, these results will be sent via email. These can also be sent to your nominated health professional. Please go to the

doctor.intro3: . WatchMeGrow.care tracks developmental progress for children aged between approximately
doctor.intro5: . It has been designed to facilitate early identification of developmental problems.
doctor.redFlag: It is highly likely that this child has developmental issues. It is recommended that a referral for further assessment and early intervention through a paediatrician or other child development health professional is completed. In addition, it is important to continue to monitor the child over time.
doctor.greenFlag: Developmental issues in this child are unlikely. No further follow-up necessary at this point. Continue ongoing monitoring as usual
doctor.moreInfo: For further information on child development please go to
doctor.parentInfo: This information has also been provided to the parent.
